awd_titl_txt: STEM Scholars Engaging in Local Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
The Eastern Mennonite University (EMU) STEM Scholars Engaging in Local Problems (SSELP) program will  provide 14 scholarships to academically talented, low-income students who will pursue employment, service, or continued education in high-need STEM  fields regionally and nationwide. This program will use the local community and the surrounding Shenandoah Valley as a rich resource to inspire and teach students STEM concepts in a hands-on, problem-to-solution based manner. Scholars will receive early and consistent exposure to inquiry- and problem-based learning through mini-research projects that are embedded in their courses and focused on real-world issues. In addition, EMU will offer a new Science and Engineering Practicum course for first year scholars.  This practicum will highlight the variety of STEM careers by providing interactions between students and STEM professionals across different careers followed by reflective writing on those experiences.  Scholarships, with several academic interventions and supports including tutoring, mentoring, career skill-building, encourage academically talented, low-income students to pursue and persist in STEM majors. These interventions are designed to heighten student commitment to serving as active, contributing citizens; build self-efficacy; engage them in their STEM studies; and help them to envision multiple STEM career pathways. 

The SSELP program will 1) recruit two cohorts of seven academically talented, low-income students majoring in biology, chemistry, biochemistry, engineering, computer science, mathematics, or environmental science; 2) retain 93% (13/14) of SSELP scholars to Year 2; 3) graduate 14 SSELP scholars in four years and place 93% of them (within one year of graduation) in jobs, service programs, or graduate programs related to STEM; and 4) generate undergraduate STEM education knowledge by exploring the extent to which a place-based interdisciplinary project develops STEM students' level of motivation for their major.  Student motivation for STEM studies will be assessed using validated surveys before and after their participation in the local-based, interdisciplinary, collaborative project.  These quantitative data will be enhanced by qualitative information gathered from semi-structured interviews with the SSELP scholars.  While the impact of place-based learning has been shown to improve engagement and motivation in primary and secondary students, there is a gap in scholarly work on this for higher education settings.  Thus, the SSELP program will also contribute to the growing knowledge on student efficacy and motivation.

por.por_cntn:
EMU designed a STEM scholarship program to engage two cohorts of seven students early in their academic studies in local problems or questions that impact the Shenandoah Valley. Our program was interdisciplinary both in the faculty mentors and the students' area of study with majors in biology, chemistry, environmental science, engineering, computer science, and math. EMU provided these academically talented, low-income students with a career practicum in year one aimed at broadening understanding of the many possibilities of STEM careers. Most of the stem scholars completed the career practicum course (13 of 14) and were connected with career services, internship opportunities, local employers, and STEM alumni. 

The second intervention aimed at increasing career understanding was incentivized, interdisciplinary student projects or research aimed at regional problems. These team projects were designed to be place-based education opportunities that applied STEM content and skills to authentic issues and contextualized learning within the cultures, ecosystems, and environment that make up home during college. While research has focused on place-based education in primary and secondary settings, the impact on student motivation and retention in higher education has not been explored. Due to the impacts of the pandemic, the interdisciplinary projects were mostly place-based. Of the three main student projects, two (“Wheelchair brakes” and “Stream assessment”) were place-based and one (“Super-mileage car”) was not.The impact of these projects on students was measured through a science motivation survey as well as focus group data. In comparison to peers not in this cohort, scholars reported less of a drop on the science motivation scales; in fact, the scholars became more motivated to engage in a STEM career while their peers were much less so. The focus group data indicates that scholars became more conscious of contributing to a community beyond themselves, including the EMU community, the local context, and the larger scientific community. 

Additionally the student scholars were provided with layers of mentoring to build a network of support and increase student sense of belonging within the STEM fields. Students were matched with a near peer mentor and two faculty mentors in year one. The faculty mentors were an academic advisor and someone from a different STEM field. The second cohort was also offered a year-long mentorship program with a STEM professional (3 of 7 participated). Students benefited from peer tutors embedded in STEM courses and often participated as tutors in their second through fourth years. 

The impact of the combination of these interventions was measured through retention and persistence to graduation and through student intent to pursue a STEM career, related service, or graduate studies. All 14 students (100%) were retained to year two in STEM. The persistence from year two to three emerged as a struggle; the overall retention to year three was 82%. The overall retention to year four was 89%, including one scholar who returned after not enrolling in year three. Overall graduation rate of scholars within four years was 80%. While the goal of 100% graduation in four years was not achieved, the persistence rates for the SSELP scholars exceeded the persistence rates of both EMU first-time, first-year STEM students and of EMU first-time, first-year students overall. At the time of this report, approximately 60% of each cohort is enrolled in a STEM graduate program or is working in a STEM related field.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/08/2024
Modified by: Tara L Kishbaugh
